content: @nikomatsakis I started collecting the story lines for the blog post review (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1obiDrXCN0T0PKuzEtU6rEe5uqHSqCzN3SEosk89P7yg/edit?usp=sharing) The biggest theme I can find is "Rust at Work". I'd like to find one other major story to balance with. I don't think all interesting findings have to fall under an overarching story but having 1 or 2 can make the blog post more interesting to read. I think last year's post was much more "a collection of stats" style.
Is there a theme for the biggest things people care about, and those things evolving from previous surveys as they're improved in Rust?
It would be nice to tell a "you asked, and we answered" story.
Unfortunately I think the story there isn't perfect. I think a lot of what has been previously talked about are still ongoing efforts like compile times
though I will note that in 2020, we have so far achieved roughly I would say 5-10% wall time improvement (https://perf.rust-lang.org/compare.html?start=2020-01-01&end=&stat=wall-time)

@Ryan Levick The story doesn't have to be perfect, it has to be a story of improvement. If we want to tell that story, we need to have addressed at least some of the things people have asked for, and be working on some of the others.
In particular, if we've addressed some of the qualitative, and made progress on some of the quantitative, that works.
https://blog.rust-lang.org/2020/09/03/Planning-2021-Roadmap.html may also be useful btw as source of progress on things (addressing roadmap more so than survey but it's similar I suspect)
@nikomatsakis can you give me access to the analysis from last year's survey? I'd like to compare what percentage of people said they use Rust at work.

I think we're fairly close to a good outline for the blog post. I have two main sections "Rust at Work" and "Stablization" that tell (mostly positive) stories about Rust along some other interesting tidbits that don't seem to fall into a shared category.
I'm also trying to think of good takeaways from the data. In general, I think there's a lot to be positive about - Rust's future seems bright, but there are some areas to further improve though none are particularly new (e.g., learnability, compile times, etc.)
@Ryan Levick yep
@Ryan Levick is it just that particular question you were interested in?
I'm reluctant to share more data than is necessary just for privacy reasons, but I could extract those aggregate results quite easily
I'm a bit surprised I don't see the number in the 2019 blog post, maybe I'm missing it
It's fine to share just the number. I might have more questions from old surveys, but it probably won't be too many
I also didn't find the number on the blog post so I thought I'd ask :-)
@Ryan Levick I'm looking forward to hearing what this survey has to say about compile times. Any early takeaways?
They need to improve ;-)
But people do think they've improved though only 5% say they've improved _a lot_
2% say they've gotten worse which is fairly high amount of "gotten worse" compared to other things we asked about
Interesting. I'd love to hear more from the people who say they've gotten worse, regarding what projects they're building.
I'd love to take those projects and put them into rustc-perf.
image.png @Ryan Levick that's from 2019
this is 2018:
image.png
I guess these are English only
(but for aggregate purposes, that's not so different)
I don't have the raw data from 2017
actually here is 2017
image.png
but I don't have 2016
I'm not sure why, but this year it seems like the total of "no applicable" was much higher. I wonder why people would answer with "not applicable"
"Not applicable" was 15.1% this year vs 11.9% last year.
The "no" answer is roughly the same as last year though if we remove "not applicable" answers it should be much lower than years past
Not applicable is my answer, because I don't work for a company or other org currently, fwiw.
Maybe we should make that explicit in future surveys (or in a separate question); do we have a list of changes we'd like to make doc yet?
No we don't. This is on my list of todos

Ryan Levick said:

I'm not sure why, but this year it seems like the total of "no applicable" was much higher. I wonder why people would answer with "not applicable"

"not applicable" is the accurate answer if you don't have a job at a company.
So, I think the answer is "2020".
I put Not Applicable for "using rust at work" because I don't work in software
'Not Applicable' for me, when I have a job, I use another lang full time, but I do use Rust for hobby project at free time. So probably increasing that number shows more frequent usage at free time.

@nikomatsakis Do you have the full data from last year with regard to people using Rust at work? In the English responses last year 36.1% indicated they use Rust at work at least part time while this year across the entire data set 33.8% said they use Rust at work at least part time. Given this would potentially be the first time ever that this percentage has gone down, I'd like to see the full data
I looked at just the English results this year and it's even a bigger difference from last year with 29.9% saying they work with Rust at least part time.
This seems like its due to a much larger percentage saying "not applicable" with 16.7% of English respondents answering so this year vs just 11.9% last year
The raw numbers story is much better for the Rust adoption story with 1098 people responding they work at least part time in 2019 vs 1544 people this year.

A vast majority of those who answered "not applicable" identify as either hobbyist or student so I guess the worse percentages can be chocked up to more people who are not actively working in software answering the question.

Though it seems that the percentage who answered "no" remained relatively constant while the answer to "yes" went down. This means out of those who gave a definitive yes or no answer, a larger percentage answered "no" this year vs last.
Last year 44.2% of those who gave a definite yes or no answer said yes, but this year only 38.9% did (of English respondents)
I'd love to talk about the theme of Rust at work, but this data certainly doesn't paint as a nice of a story as I was hoping.

This year is a clear win over 2018 though with 30.1% of all respondents saying they use Rust at work in 2018 vs 33.8% this year. Last year's survey was much smaller than this year's and 2018's. I'm wondering if that skewed the data.
@Ryan Levick hmm
tbh I'm not sure how much this static really means
I guess though that we have the total combined data from last year, though i'm not sure where it is, let me go look
@Jasun Carr may still have it lying around too
@Ryan Levick From what you're saying, the story may be "more adoption across the board; more growth outside work than at work". I can imagine reasons for that; depends on the rest of the data.

@nikomatsakis at the bottom of the outline, I've written a rough draft of the post. We still need to add charts and figures, but I'm mostly happy with the stories it tells: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1obiDrXCN0T0PKuzEtU6rEe5uqHSqCzN3SEosk89P7yg/edit?usp=sharing
@Ryan Levick cool! looking now
(one thought about the post is that we often include charts and things)
as well as some coverage of the demographics and so forth
(but the story is more important, that stuff is kind of "window dressing")
OK, I read it! Very interested. I loved some of the analysis you did
(Oh, I guess you already said "we still need to add charts and figures")
BTW, @Josh Triplett, I think the results in the draft above (not sure if you have access...) inform a bit the lang-team roadmap discussion we were having, although I think they're compatible
I was already stressing "interop", and certainly a big theme is "C++ interop"
One thing I notice that you didn't cover that much is what people were excited about
I thought that was interesting and worth covering

something else I'm wondering: anecdotally, I hear a lot of requests for "better/more-stable ecosystem". I think this is a combination of things like "more 1.0 crates, easier to find the right crate, crates for more niche use cases". Did you see that as any kind of theme in the results?

nikomatsakis said:

One thing I notice that you didn't cover that much is what people were excited about

Yes I was planning on adding this as well :+1:

nikomatsakis said:

something else I'm wondering: anecdotally, I hear a lot of requests for "better/more-stable ecosystem". I think this is a combination of things like "more 1.0 crates, easier to find the right crate, crates for more niche use cases". Did you see that as any kind of theme in the results?

Yes though I didn't gather a lot of insight. I'd like to highlight GUI as being a much asked for need. Beyond that, I think maybe just adding a sentence that states what you said would be helpful
@Ryan Levick yeah I think that just highlighting that it's a persistently cited need is the main thing
@nikomatsakis would you be able to help me decide which charts and figures we want to include?
Sure, how would you like me to do that ...
I guess it's worth comparing a bit against prior posts
Insert FIGURE: ${DESCRIPTION OF FIGURE} into the blog post
to be honest, I never personally get that much from some of the intro demographic material, but we do usually lead with that
ok
I personally have found the figures from past blog posts to be less than insightful. My goal with this post was to try to leave out unactionable information.
Now, figures and charts _are_ pretty and do help make the post more visually interesting so I'm fine including 1 or 2 that are just visually interesting even if they're not that actionable
yeah I think it's partly an aesthetic thing
I added in some suggestions
one thing I noticed in the Improved Learnability section is
it's hard to decide what to include because a lot of the stats are kind of "conditional" distributions
I do think it's kind of useful to show the distribution and not only talk about averages
one thing I think might be worth including @Ryan Levick in the "learnability" section is just showing the "how much of an expert do you think you are" question
I don't know how it compares to other languages, but it seems notable that so few people say 10 :)
(that may just be normal though)
but I could imagine leading with that overall graph and then digging a bit more into specifics for example
and/or showing two variants of the graph at the end, one for folks who use rust regularly and one for folks who don't
I'd like that
(off topic but related: I'd love to start a learning working group that investigated how to make Rust easier to learn)
yes
I'm adding some thoughts into Improved Learnability along these lines
they're all "google suggestions"
to make it easier to track

(btw, not sure if anybody else on this stream might be interested in helping to make figures, and not to speak for @Ryan Levick, but I imagine that he might appreciate the help if somebody did want to do so)
Yes, I actually am not sure how best to make the figures. They looked very nice in the previous blog posts.
I think we usually go for google sheets charts feature, but those can be hard to export. Probably the ideal is something like gnuplot svgs, but those need some work to make them look nice
(in particular we want svg or at least high resolution because otherwise it's hard to look at details on the chart and it can get blurry)
I believe @XAMPPRocky made them last year
Perhaps they have some tips :)

Last year we used Google Sheets Charts exported as SVGs, using the excel spreadsheet of data. The one thing I remember being a pain is that the export can look different than the version in Google sheets if the chart is compact, so make sure there’s enough spacing between bars in the graph.
@nikomatsakis I figured out how to make SVG graphs, and the post is now up as a PR on the blog repo: https://github.com/rust-lang/blog.rust-lang.org/pull/736
@Ryan Levick really great summary, a big :thumbs_up: for putting those numbers into words
Thanks!
@nikomatsakis I have the blog post scheduled for tomorrow. Any objections to that? I just need a final review by then
@simulacrum when did we plan for the foundation-related blog post, Wednesday?
There are two I think, one today and another on wednesday
roadmap goes out thursday
Oh!
Ah, yeah, I keep forgetting about the post that @Florian Gilcher was writing :P
OK, it'll be a busy week, but that seems ok
I think Tuesday will be fine yeah
rustdoc also has a post on Friday I believe
I am not sure rustdoc will go out
@Ryan Levick I'm giving a quick, final read
but in any case seems fine
@Ryan Levick left one suggestion, but otherwise I think this looks great! :heart:
@Ryan Levick so we were thinking yesterday that maybe Wed would be a good day to merge this post
just because we had the foundation post yesterday
there was a thought of having another foundation post on wed but I think we decided to push that until later
(cc @simulacrum)
that said, if you would prefer to merge it today, speak up
Yes I think Wednesday would be good
We'll want to bump the date on the post
Ok sure. We can hold off until tomorrow. This will be my first blog post on the Rust blog so I’m not exactly sure what the procedure is
Not really much procedure - someone on core will merge the blog post tomorrow (likely Niko or myself), before then we just need the filename to have the 16th as the date
